PRs missing backports.title: gh-134262: increase retries in `Tools/build/generate_sbom.py`
PRs missing backports.body:
- Increase max retry count to 7
- Increase base of exponential backoff to 2.25
- Add jitter in case there is some issue with sending requests at the same time
- Also print the location that fails

The retry backoff now ranges from 1 second to 130 seconds.

<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-134262 -->
* Issue: gh-134262
<!-- /gh-issue-number -->

PRs missing backports.title: gh-134262: Add retries to generate_sbom.py
PRs missing backports.body:
`Tools/build/generate_sbom.py` downloads artifacts, which can flake. This commit adds simple exponential back-off retries to the download to avoid failures due to network flakes.

<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-134262 -->
* Issue: gh-134262
<!-- /gh-issue-number -->

PRs missing backports.title: gh-130595: Keep traceback alive for WITH_EXCEPT_START
PRs missing backports.body:
The WITH_EXCEPT_START opcode is getting the traceback from the exception object and then passing it down via a vectorcall, but only after decref'ing the traceback. 

But the exception object can have the only reference to the traceback. If the receiver of the traceback does something to cause the exception's trace back to be replaced, then uses the traceback, they access dangling pointer. The traceback shouldn't solely be kept alive by the exception object which can be mutated.

<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-130595 -->
* Issue: gh-130595
<!-- /gh-issue-number -->

PRs missing backports.title: gh-102988: Detect email address parsing errors and return empty tuple to indicate the parsing error (old API)
PRs missing backports.body:
This PR is designed to detect parsing errors and return an empty tuple to indicate the parsing error. Additionally, this PR updates the `test_email.py` to check for these bugs, as well as, adds some other wacky Address Headers that are in the examples of RFC 2822 and makes sure they are being parsed correctly.

I realize that this PR dose not actually track down the bug and fix it. It simply detects the error has happened and returns a parsing error. However, `Lib/email/utils.py` is a much simpler file than `Lib/email/_parseaddr.py`, so it is much easier to review this change. Additionally, there are actually multiple bugs which are causing erroneous  output. Tracing the code flow for each and fixing them would be prone to error considering all of the wacky stuff that RFC 2822 allows for in Address headers. Finally, this change is actually rather simple.

<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-102988 -->
* Issue: gh-102988
<!-- /gh-issue-number -->

PRs missing backports.title: gh-80222: Fix email address header folding with long quoted-string
PRs missing backports.body:
Fixes #80222 (bpo-36041).

Email generators using email.policy.default could incorrectly omit the quote ('"') characters from a quoted-string during header refolding, leading to invalid address headers and enabling header spoofing. This change restores the quote characters on a bare-quoted-string as the header is refolded, and escapes backslash and quote chars in the string.

Fix is adapted from PR #12054.

[This fixes a #security-issue. PSRT instructed me to handle the fix publicly.]


<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-80222 -->
* Issue: gh-80222
<!-- /gh-issue-number -->
